newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak govt approves import surcharge - paper.
newsitem.headline: Slovak govt approves import surcharge - paper.

text.p: The Slovak government has approved the introduction of an import surcharge, the economic daily Hospodarske Noviny reported on Wednesday.

The paper, quoting "confidential" government material, said the cabinet approved the surcharge on Tuesday, but gave no further information. The official agenda of the regular cabinet session did not include any such item.
The government's spokeswoman was not available for comment and other press department officials refused to comment.
"I cannot comment on it. If there was anything like this at the session, it must have been confidential material," said one official who declined to give her name.
Added Finance Ministry spokesman Jozef Mach: "We have no information about any such document." He refused to comment further.

Slovakia has long been fighting the widening trend of its trade deficit and the government officials have said Bratislava may introduce an import surcharge to help reverse the trade balance develpment
The foreign trade deficit widened to 29.859 billion crowns for the January-May period of 1997, from 27.908 billion crowns in the first four months of this year.
Slovakia abolished a widely-criticised import surcharge at the beginning of this year, after cutting it to 7.5 percent from the original 10 percent in July 1996.

In an attempt to curb the trade deficit, Bratislava introduced an unpopular import deposit measure last May, requiring importers to place an equivalent of 20 percent of their imports on an interest-free accounts for six months.
Slovak government said the European Union had demanded the abolition of the import deposit measure arguing that it would rather accept an import surcharge.
